Ultramarine Violet [GEN | AS | BA.o | BX.o.w | CAS.k | DR.w | DS.ad.o.w | DV.k.w | EP.p | GB.o.o |GO.a.af.ao | GU.pd | KA.p | LK | MA.o.o(artis).p.w | MG.a.o | MH.o | OH.a.o.w | RF.e | RGH.o.p | RT.o.w | SCH.p | SE.a.o.p | SQ.a | UT.o | WL.o.o(SF).p | WN.a.o.w.wp]

The creation of Ultramarine Violet is carried out by heating at 200–250°C a mixture of ultramarine blue and 2.5–5% ammonium chloride. It takes 4 days of calcining while being exposed to the air until a purple hue is created.

Ultramarine Red is derived from ultramarine violet by heating it for four hours with gaseous hydrochloric acid at 200°C. It's creation can also be accomplished by heating ultramarine violet at a even higher temperatures with gaseous nitric acid (Reference Pigment Compendium, 2008)

column1: CAS 6358-30-1 (no longer used, see Wikipedia)","Deep dark blue or red shade purple
there are blue shade & red shade versions of this pigment.
Very staining w/ excellent tinting strength

† Fades",S/T,II,A,"* PV23 Red Shade has ASTM I 'excellent' in oils & acrylics (2003), but less in watercolor with a rating of ASMT II 'very good' (2003), the Blue Shade has poorer lightfastness and is only ASTM II 'very good' (2003) in oils and IV 'poor' (ASMT ca. 1999) in watercolor.
Most Paint manufactures give it a 'very good' light fastness rating.

In real world tests on watercolor paints, Bruce MacEvoy of Handprint.com gives this pigment a II (very good), with a wide variation between brands, with most getting very good results and some with mediocre results and one giving very poor results. It also appears that, in some brands, the pigment was highly extended (diluted) which, almost certainly, was the cause of their poorer light fastness. Also variances might be due to brands using different RS or BS varieties of this pigment, and not accurately marking it on the paints. (Ref Handprint.com).
Guerra Paint & Pigment rate their water dispersion as a blue wool scale of 8 in mass tone and 7-8 in tints which is clearly in the excellent category (probably a red shade).
It stands to reason that source, extenders, manufacturing process or impurities also play a role in the light fastness of this pigment. Different mediums or binders may also give different results.
I would suggest making your own tests on the formulation or brand of artist paint you have."
